Netanyahu, spoke at the Capitol on Wednesday. But the Republican nominee for president, Donald J. Trump, appeared less impressed with Israel's messaging the next day.\n\nIsrael must end the war in Gaza \"and get it done quickly,\" Mr. Trump said in an interview on Fox News on Thursday. {"uri": "2024-07-433814762", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:54:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:54:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:30:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/israel-conflict/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_a0730f5b-1730-5dc3-ba0d-6b495d30cc53.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited the White House to discuss the war in Gaza with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris at an important moment for all three politicians\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nHarris said in remarks after what she called a \"frank and constructive meeting\" with the Israeli leader that she supports Israel's right to defend itself, but said, \"how it does so matters.\"\n\nShe expressed concern over the \"devastating\" humanitarian situation in Gaza and images of civilians killed in the conflict, saying, \"We cannot look away in the face of these tragedies.\"\n\nShe echoed Biden in calling for a swift cease-fire to end the fighting, at least for a time, to boost humanitarian aid to Gaza and release some of the most vulnerable hostages from Hamas captivity.\n\nWhite House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" White House national security spokesman John Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She is also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when former President Donald Trump was in office, is headed to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups-and-downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her as insufficient in her support for Israel.\n\nA senior administration official, who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House, said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes. He made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris on Thursday said she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\n\"Pro-Hamas graffiti and rhetoric is abhorrent and we must not tolerate it in our nation,\" Harris said in a statement. \"I condemn the burning of the American flag. That flag is a symbol of our highest ideals as a nation and represents the promise of America. It should never be desecrated in that way.\"\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. The vice president is the president of the Senate and would typically co-preside over such an event with the House speaker, Republican Mike Johnson. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nHarris has long spoken of her strong support for Israel. The first overseas trip of her Senate career in early 2017 was to Israel, and one of her first acts in office was to introduce a resolution opposing a U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israel.\n\nShe's also spoken of her personal ties to Israel, including memories of raising money as a child to plant trees in Israel, installing a mezuzah near the front door of the vice president's residence in Washington (her husband is Jewish) and her connections to pro-Israel groups including the conservative American Israel Public Affairs Committee and the liberal J Street.\n\nHarris has largely been in lockstep with Biden throughout the conflict, but at moments she's been a front-runner for tougher Biden administration rhetoric on Israel.\n\nShe used a high-profile address in March in Selma, Alabama, a day before she met with Netanyahu rival and Israeli war cabinet member Benny Gantz to decry Palestinians \"starving\" in the face of \"inhumane\" conditions and to urge Israel to do more to alleviate civilian suffering in Gaza.\n\n-- -\n\nAP writer Ashraf Khalil contributed reporting.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. {"uri": "2024-07-433828206", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:22:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:22:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://omaha.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_eb2438b1-c84c-53da-aa95-dff3e4060f07.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "Days after launching her White House campaign, U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the vice president's ceremonial office. Netanyahu also met with President Joe Biden earlier in the day.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She was also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when Republican Donald Trump was president, will head to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups and downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her support for Israel as insufficient.\n\nA senior administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes.\n\nHe made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris said Thursday she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nBiden speech: President appeals to Americans in solemn address", "source": {"uri": "omaha.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8243823783", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:52:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:52:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:51:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://dailyprogress.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_780ba68e-421b-58ad-af85-29ede4627bc8.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She was also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when Republican Donald Trump was president, will head to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups and downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her support for Israel as insufficient.\n\nA senior administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes.\n\nHe made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris said Thursday she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. {"uri": "2024-07-433818919", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:03:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:03:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:30:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_5de0ddb6-e9fd-5638-b326-ce57a676a0a2.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nHarris said in remarks after what she called a \"frank and constructive meeting\" with the Israeli leader that she supports Israel's right to defend itself, but said, \"how it does so matters.\"\n\nShe expressed concern over the \"devastating\" humanitarian situation in Gaza and images of civilians killed in the conflict, saying, \"We cannot look away in the face of these tragedies.\"\n\nShe echoed Biden in calling for a swift cease-fire to end the fighting, at least for a time, to boost humanitarian aid to Gaza and release some of the most vulnerable hostages from Hamas captivity.\n\nWhite House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" White House national security spokesman John Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She is also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when former President Donald Trump was in office, is headed to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups-and-downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her as insufficient in her support for Israel.\n\nA senior administration official, who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House, said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes. He made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris on Thursday said she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\n\"Pro-Hamas graffiti and rhetoric is abhorrent and we must not tolerate it in our nation,\" Harris said in a statement. \"I condemn the burning of the American flag. That flag is a symbol of our highest ideals as a nation and represents the promise of America. It should never be desecrated in that way.\"\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. The vice president is the president of the Senate and would typically co-preside over such an event with the House speaker, Republican Mike Johnson. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nHarris has long spoken of her strong support for Israel. The first overseas trip of her Senate career in early 2017 was to Israel, and one of her first acts in office was to introduce a resolution opposing a U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israel.\n\nShe's also spoken of her personal ties to Israel, including memories of raising money as a child to plant trees in Israel, installing a mezuzah near the front door of the vice president's residence in Washington (her husband is Jewish) and her connections to pro-Israel groups including the conservative American Israel Public Affairs Committee and the liberal J Street.\n\nHarris has largely been in lockstep with Biden throughout the conflict, but at moments she's been a front-runner for tougher Biden administration rhetoric on Israel.\n\nShe used a high-profile address in March in Selma, Alabama, a day before she met with Netanyahu rival and Israeli war cabinet member Benny Gantz to decry Palestinians \"starving\" in the face of \"inhumane\" conditions and to urge Israel to do more to alleviate civilian suffering in Gaza.\n\n-- -\n\nAP writer Ashraf Khalil contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", {"uri": "8243822089", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:50:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:50:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:49:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://dothaneagle.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_6dcd0948-c5c8-5c00-9d3f-bb5687686d2c.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She was also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when Republican Donald Trump was president, will head to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups and downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her support for Israel as insufficient.\n\nA senior administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes.\n\nHe made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris said Thursday she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nBiden speech: President appeals to Americans in solemn address Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9764144", "eventUri": "eng-9764144", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Washington, D.C."}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "2024-07-433817713", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:01:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:01:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:23:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.wthr.com/article/news/nation-world/israel-hamas-conflict/netanyahu-will-meet-with-biden-and-harris/507-f4f796c0-4724-4c95-914b-6b15c62dd474", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "Biden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited the White House Thursday to discuss the war in Gaza -- and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal -- with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris is scheduled to meet separately on Thursday with Netanyahu. She is also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when former President Donald Trump was in office, is headed to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups-and-downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her as insufficient in her support for Israel.\n\nA senior administration official, who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House, said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, in a fiery address before a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes. He made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris on Thursday said she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\n\"Pro-Hamas graffiti and rhetoric is abhorrent and we must not tolerate it in our nation,\" Harris said in a statement. \"I condemn the burning of the American flag. That flag is a symbol of our highest ideals as a nation and represents the promise of America. It should never be desecrated in that way.\"\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. The vice president is the president of the Senate and would typically co-preside over such an event with the House speaker, Republican Mike Johnson. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nHarris has long spoken of her strong support for Israel. The first overseas trip of her Senate career in early 2017 was to Israel, and one of her first acts in office was to introduce a resolution opposing a U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israel.\n\nShe's also spoken of her personal ties to Israel, including memories of raising money as a child to plant trees in Israel, installing a mezuzah near the front door of the vice president's residence in Washington (her husband is Jewish) and her connections to pro-Israel groups including the conservative American Israel Public Affairs Committee and the liberal J Street.\n\nHarris has largely been in lockstep with Biden throughout the conflict, but at moments she's been a front-runner for tougher Biden administration rhetoric on Israel.\n\nShe used a high-profile address in March in Selma, Alabama, a day before she met with Netanyahu rival and Israeli war cabinet member Benny Gantz to decry Palestinians \"starving\" in the face of \"inhumane\" conditions and to urge Israel to do more to alleviate civilian suffering in Gaza.", "source": {"uri": "wthr.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTHR-TV 13 NBC Indianapolis"}, "authors": {"uri": "8243836122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-26", "time": "00:09:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-26T00:09:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-26T00:08:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://floridapolitics.com/archives/686357-kamala-harris-tells-benjamin-netanyahu-it-is-time-to-get-hostage-deal-done-and-end-gaza-war/", "title": "Kamala Harris tells Benjamin Netanyahu 'it is time' to get hostage deal done and end Gaza war", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris on Thursday said she urged Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to reach a cease-fire deal soon with Hamas so that dozens of hostages held by the militants in Gaza since Oct. 7 can return home.\n\nHarris said she had a \"frank and constructive\" conversation with Netanyahu in which she affirmed Israel's right to defend itself but also expressed deep concern about the high death toll in Gaza over nine months of war and the \"dire\" humanitarian situation there.\n\nWith all eyes on the likely Democratic nominee, Harris largely reiterated Biden's longstanding message that it's time find an endgame to the brutal war in Gaza, where more than 39,000 Palestinians have died. Yet she offered a more forceful tone about the urgency of the moment just one day after Netanyahu gave a fiery speech to Congress in which he defended the war, vowed \"total victory\" against Hamas and made relatively scant mention of cease-fire negotiations.\n\n\"There has been hopeful movement in the talks to secure an agreement on this deal,\" Harris told reporters shortly after meeting with Netanyahu. \"And as I just told Prime Minister Netanyahu, it is time to get this deal done.\"\n\nNetanyahu met separately earlier in the day with President Joe Biden, who has also been calling on Israel and Hamas to come to an agreement on a U.S.-backed, three-phase deal to bring home remaining hostages and establish an extended cease-fire.\n\nHarris said following her meeting with Netanyahu that Israel's war in Gaza is more complicated than simply about people being supportive of one side or the other.\n\n\"Too often, the conversation is binary when the reality is anything but,\" Harris said.\n\nHarris also condemned Hamas' brutality. White House National Security Council spokesman John Kirby reiterated the administration position that the militant group that killed some 1,200 on Oct. 7 and kidnapped 250 people from Israel ultimately holds responsibility for the suffering in Gaza and must come to terms with Israel.\n\nKirby added that gaps between the two sides can be closed \"but there are issues that need to be resolved that will require some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nWith Harris' forceful comments, the administration also appeared to be stepping up pressure on the Israelis to not let the moment pass to get a deal done.\n\n\"What has happened in Gaza over the past nine months is devastating. The images of dead children and desperate, hungry people fleeing for safety, sometimes displaced for the second, third or fourth time,\" Harris said. \"We cannot look away in the face of these tragedies. We cannot allow ourselves to become numb to the suffering. And I will not be silent.\"\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when former President Donald Trump was in office, is headed to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nAhead of the Harris-Netanyahu meeting on Thursday, Trump said at a rally in North Carolina the Vice President was \"totally against the Jewish people.\"\n\nHarris has long spoken of her strong support for Israel. The first overseas trip of her Senate career in early 2017 was to Israel, and one of her first acts in office was to introduce a resolution opposing a U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israel.\n\nShe's also spoken of her personal ties to Israel, including memories of raising money as a child to plant trees in Israel, installing a mezuzah near the front door of the Vice President's residence in Washington (her husband is Jewish) and her connections to pro-Israel groups including the conservative American Israel Public Affairs Committee and the liberal J Street.\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu was an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as Commander in Chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her as insufficient in her support for Israel.\n\nHarris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups-and-downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the President for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes. He made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu also derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris on Thursday said she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\n\"Pro-Hamas graffiti and rhetoric is abhorrent and we must not tolerate it in our nation,\" Harris said in a statement. \"I condemn the burning of the American flag. That flag is a symbol of our highest ideals as a nation and represents the promise of America. It should never be desecrated in that way.\"\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\n___\n\nRepublished with permission of The Associated Press.", "source": {"uri": "floridapolitics.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Florida Politics - Campaigns & Elections. "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Nationalism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Nationalism", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://floridapolitics.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Kamala-Harris-Benjamin-Netanyahu.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9764144", "eventUri": "eng-9764144", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-10-07", "textStart": 204, "textEnd": 210, "freq": 2}], "sentiment": -0.2235294117647059, "wgt": 211, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243790799", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:08:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:08:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:07:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/watch-harris-outlines-steps-in-gaza-cease-fire-proposal-after-meeting-with-israels-netanyahu", "title": "WATCH: Harris outlines steps in Gaza cease-fire proposal after meeting with Israel's Netanyahu", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nWatch Harris' remarks in the player above.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nWATCH: Mideast analysts weigh in on Netanyahu's address and if it could affect support for Israel\n\nHarris said in remarks after what she called a \"frank and constructive meeting\" with the Israeli leader that she supports Israel's right to defend itself, but said, \"how it does so matters.\"\n\nShe expressed concern over the \"devastating\" humanitarian situation in Gaza and images of civilians killed in the conflict, saying, \"We cannot look away in the face of these tragedies.\"\n\nShe echoed Biden in calling for a swift cease-fire to end the fighting, at least for a time, to boost humanitarian aid to Gaza and release some of the most vulnerable hostages from Hamas captivity.\n\nWhite House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" White House national security spokesman John Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She is also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when former President Donald Trump was in office, is headed to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups-and-downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her as insufficient in her support for Israel.\n\nA senior administration official, who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House, said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes. He made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris on Thursday said she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\n\"Pro-Hamas graffiti and rhetoric is abhorrent and we must not tolerate it in our nation,\" Harris said in a statement. \"I condemn the burning of the American flag. That flag is a symbol of our highest ideals as a nation and represents the promise of America. It should never be desecrated in that way.\"\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. The vice president is the president of the Senate and would typically co-preside over such an event with the House speaker, Republican Mike Johnson. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nHarris has long spoken of her strong support for Israel. The first overseas trip of her Senate career in early 2017 was to Israel, and one of her first acts in office was to introduce a resolution opposing a U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israel.\n\nShe's also spoken of her personal ties to Israel, including memories of raising money as a child to plant trees in Israel, installing a mezuzah near the front door of the vice president's residence in Washington (her husband is Jewish) and her connections to pro-Israel groups including the conservative American Israel Public Affairs Committee and the liberal J Street.\n\nHarris has largely been in lockstep with Biden throughout the conflict, but at moments she's been a front-runner for tougher Biden administration rhetoric on Israel.\n\nShe used a high-profile address in March in Selma, Alabama, a day before she met with Netanyahu rival and Israeli war cabinet member Benny Gantz to decry Palestinians \"starving\" in the face of \"inhumane\" conditions and to urge Israel to do more to alleviate civilian suffering in Gaza.\n\nAP writer Ashraf Khalil contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "pbs.org", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8243799910", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:19:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:19:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:18:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://newsadvance.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_0c247538-ee9e-5ad9-8370-844ec5c05fa5.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She was also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when Republican Donald Trump was president, will head to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups and downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her support for Israel as insufficient.\n\nA senior administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes.\n\nHe made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris said Thursday she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that {"uri": "8243787431", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:03:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:03:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:02:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/news/national/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_6b65613d-35d2-5a7d-8317-f0165935ec7c.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "U.S. Capitol police watch demonstrators marching outside of the U.S. Capitol as they protest the visit of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Capitol Hill, Wednesday, July 24, 2024, in Washington.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited the White House Thursday to discuss the war in Gaza -- and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal -- with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris is scheduled to meet separately on Thursday with Netanyahu. She is also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when former President Donald Trump was in office, is headed to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups-and-downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her as insufficient in her support for Israel.\n\nA senior administration official, who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House, said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, in a fiery address before a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes. He made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris on Thursday said she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\n\"Pro-Hamas graffiti and rhetoric is abhorrent and we must not tolerate it in our nation,\" Harris said in a statement. \"I condemn the burning of the American flag. That flag is a symbol of our highest ideals as a nation and represents the promise of America. It should never be desecrated in that way.\"\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. The vice president is the president of the Senate and would typically co-preside over such an event with the House speaker, Republican Mike Johnson. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nHarris has long spoken of her strong support for Israel. The first overseas trip of her Senate career in early 2017 was to Israel, and one of her first acts in office was to introduce a resolution opposing a U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israel.\n\nShe's also spoken of her personal ties to Israel, including memories of raising money as a child to plant trees in Israel, installing a mezuzah near the front door of the vice president's residence in Washington (her husband is Jewish) and her connections to pro-Israel groups including the conservative American Israel Public Affairs Committee and the liberal J Street.\n\nHarris has largely been in lockstep with Biden throughout the conflict, but at moments she's been a front-runner for tougher Biden administration rhetoric on Israel.\n\nShe used a high-profile address in March in Selma, Alabama, a day before she met with Netanyahu rival and Israeli war cabinet member Benny Gantz to decry Palestinians \"starving\" in the face of \"inhumane\" conditions and to urge Israel to do more to alleviate civilian suffering in Gaza.\n\n-- -\n\nAP writer Ashraf Khalil contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com",
