{"uri": "8243802653", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:22:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:22:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:20:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_ff69b0b1-ca7c-5a60-9949-4f218cfca413.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington teen rebuilds landscape of alma mater for Eagle Scout project Riverdale man gets 123 years for 2020 murder in Bloomington Man struck by gunfire early Saturday in north Normal Video: Springfield woman ducked, apologized before fatal police shooting McLean County Fair selects 2024 royalty Pritzker, Illinois leaders react to Biden leaving presidential race 'Shocked, horrified,' Illinois leaders condemn police killing of Sonya Massey Funerals today for July 23 Flick Fact: That J.D. Vance beard and its McLean County significance? U High senior Jeremy Coleman willing his way to volleyball future Normal police investigating shots fired Tuesday night Ronald & Wanda Coyne Update: Canton police say missing 2-year-old has been found alive McLean County Fair food vendors offer something for everyone \ud83c\udf2d Bloomington man detained, accused of sexually assaulting teen at knifepoint\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She was also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when Republican Donald Trump was president, will head to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups and downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her support for Israel as insufficient.\n\nA senior administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes.\n\nHe made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris said Thursday she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nBiden speech: President appeals to Americans in solemn address Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to {"uri": "8243835483", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-26", "time": "00:08:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-26T00:08:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-26T00:08:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_444494f2-86a2-5851-ba2c-44bf3eb7cf01.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man who had himself banned from Iowa casinos wins jackpot at the Isle UPDATE: 69 John Deere Waterloo salaried employees let go Wednesday, 34 in Dubuque Chased out of Buchanan County, Balance music festival coming to Waterloo Waterloo traffic cameras adjust ticket threshold by 1 mph State: NewAldaya Lifescapes resident suffocated while trapped in bed rails NEW DETAILS: Deere offers statement on severance package for salaried employees let go Wednesday in Waterloo Teen seriously injured in Dunkerton rollover crash Denver girls' track coach fired for unknown reason despite petition from community UPDATE: Man who died in lawnmower accident was Don Bosco teacher College Wrestling: UNI receives major gift toward new training facility Name released in Hudson fatal shooting Neighbors, crews rescue man from sinking vehicle UPDATE: 15 year old injured in reported shooting 2024 Iowa Shrine Bowl: North squad downs South in offensive shootout Waterloo woman who dumped 13 pounds of meth in chase sent to prison\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She was also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when Republican Donald Trump was president, will head to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups and downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her support for Israel as insufficient.\n\nA senior administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes.\n\nHe made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris said Thursday she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nBiden speech: President appeals to Americans in solemn address 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe {"uri": "2024-07-433827982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:21:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:21:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_196d5306-0a2f-5c01-9356-d81a06c67e39.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "Days after launching her White House campaign, U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the vice president's ceremonial office. Netanyahu also met with President Joe Biden earlier in the day.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nNorthwoods Falls closes in St. John, owners hope temporarily Davich: Frankly, this is the best hot dog joint in the Region Mascot Hall of Fame to close in September, 'going out with confetti' UPDATE: Valpo man identified as motorcyclist killed when SUV reportedly made sudden U-turn Valpo jewelry store burglarized; holes cut in wall, cops say Valparaiso tornado confirmed as county calls state in for help Former Lake County councilman could avoid jail time yet again in 3rd domestic battery case Crown Point man led chase, soiled police vehicle, report says Portage officers injured during high-speed chase with bikers armed with AK-47, report says UPDATE: Cedar Lake woman killed in Monday's storm remembered as 'rock of the family' Region police release photo of wanted man Big Lots closing stores in Chicagoland and Indiana, warns it may close all stores NWI Business Ins and Outs: Royale with Cheese, Top of the Morning, Casa Blanca, Estella's Cantina, El Jimador, Jet's Pizza, Wingstop and Wing Snob opening Ex-Crown Point real estate agents indicted on charges of $5 million in COVID relief fraud after allegedly spending money on Porsche and country club Sunday night house fire draws out several departments\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She was also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when Republican Donald Trump was president, will head to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups and downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her support for Israel as insufficient.\n\nA senior administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes.\n\nHe made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris said Thursday she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nBiden speech: President appeals to Americans in solemn {"uri": "8243832162", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-26", "time": "00:04:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-26T00:04:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-26T00:03:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/harris-tells-netanyahu-it-is-time-to-get-hostage-deal-done-and-end-gaza-war/article_ac5d0381-b338-58c7-a4dc-44db8da09ee6.html", "title": "Harris tells Netanyahu 'it is time' to get hostage deal done and end Gaza war", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris on Thursday said she urged Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to reach a cease-fire deal soon with Hamas so that dozens of hostages held by the militants in Gaza since Oct. 7 can return home.\n\nHarris said she had a \"frank and constructive\" conversation with Netanyahu in which she affirmed Israel's right to defend itself but also expressed deep concern about the high death toll in Gaza over nine months of war and the \"dire\" humanitarian situation there.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nWith all eyes on the likely Democratic nominee, Harris largely reiterated Biden's longstanding message that it's time find an endgame to the brutal war in Gaza, where more than 39,000 Palestinians have died. Yet she offered a more forceful tone about the urgency of the moment just one day after Netanyahu gave a fiery speech to Congress in which he defended the war, vowed \"total victory\" against Hamas and made relatively scant mention of cease-fire negotiations.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"There has been hopeful movement in the talks to secure an agreement on this deal,\" Harris told reporters shortly after meeting with Netanyahu. \"And as I just told Prime Minister Netanyahu, it is time to get this deal done.\"\n\nNetanyahu met separately earlier in the day with President Joe Biden, who has also been calling on Israel and Hamas to come to an agreement on a U.S.-backed, three-phase deal to bring home remaining hostages and establish an extended cease-fire.\n\nHarris said following her meeting with Netanyahu that Israel's war in Gaza is more complicated than simply about people being supportive of one side or the other.\n\n\"Too often, the conversation is binary when the reality is anything but,\" Harris said.\n\nHarris also condemned Hamas' brutality. White House national security council spokesman John Kirby reiterated the administration position that the militant group that killed some 1,200 on Oct. 7 and kidnapped 250 people from Israel ultimately holds responsibility for the suffering in Gaza and must come to terms with Israel.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nKirby added that gaps between the two sides can be closed \"but there are issues that need to be resolved that will require some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nWith Harris' forceful comments, the administration also appeared to be stepping up pressure on the Israelis to not let the moment pass to get a deal done.\n\n\"What has happened in Gaza over the past nine months is devastating. The images of dead children and desperate, hungry people fleeing for safety, sometimes displaced for the second, third or fourth time,\" Harris said. \"We cannot look away in the face of these tragedies. We cannot allow ourselves to become numb to the suffering. And I will not be silent.\"\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when former President Donald Trump was in office, is headed to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAhead of the Harris-Netanyahu meeting on Thursday, Trump said at a rally in North Carolina the vice president was \"totally against the Jewish people.\"\n\nHarris has long spoken of her strong support for Israel. The first overseas trip of her Senate career in early 2017 was to Israel, and one of her first acts in office was to introduce a resolution opposing a U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israel.\n\nShe's also spoken of her personal ties to Israel, including memories of raising money as a child to plant trees in Israel, installing a mezuzah near the front door of the vice president's residence in Washington (her husband is Jewish) and her connections to pro-Israel groups including the conservative American Israel Public Affairs Committee and the liberal J Street.\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu was an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her as insufficient in her support for Israel.\n\nHarris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups-and-downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes. He made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu also derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris on Thursday said she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\n\"Pro-Hamas graffiti and rhetoric is abhorrent and we must not tolerate it in our nation,\" Harris said in a statement. \"I condemn the burning of the American flag. That flag is a symbol of our highest ideals as a nation and represents the promise of America. It should never be desecrated in that way.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\n-- -\n\nAP writer Ashraf Khalil contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8243805138", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:25:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:25:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:24:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_5e908ca0-c3f8-5798-a723-c736833f3fc9.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\nPeople are also reading... National Ice Cream Day 2024: Get cool deals and freebies at Dairy Queen, Cold Stone and more HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: All Wolves now playing at West Ridge Bristol Casino records solid $14.35M month during June Kilgore remembered as \"larger than life\" trailblazer Housing complex rehab in Saltville wins $2.4 million state loan Campus keeps tradition strong Only the name has changed; 'The Classic' expected to become bigger and better This theater season brings friendship, camaraderie and nostalgia to the stage Owens will be missed at annual Creeper Trail Ride to End Cancer PREP SPORTS: VHSL leaders hold public meeting in Abingdon Herald Courier receives awards from Tennessee Press Association BRIEFS: VHSL to hold public forum at Abingdon on Wednesday; Top-15 finish for Adam Hooker (Lebanon) at State Open of Virginia HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Next man up part of high school football PREP FOOTBALL: Marquee games await Northeast Tennessee teams HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Versatile Elliott to see plenty of the field for Vikings\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She was also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when Republican Donald Trump was president, will head to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups and downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her support for Israel as insufficient.\n\nA senior administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes.\n\nHe made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris said Thursday she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nBiden speech: President appeals to Americans in solemn address Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to {"uri": "8243702454", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:16:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:16:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:15:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-gaza-war-ceasefire-deal/article68447278.ece", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden, Harris to narrow gaps on Gaza war ceasefire deal", "body": "Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited the White House Thursday to discuss the war in Gaza -- and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal -- with U.S. President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nJoe Biden says he ended 2024 U.S. presidential bid to unite Democratic party\n\nMr. Netanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\n'Gaps are closable'\n\nMr. Biden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a ceasefire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Mr. Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\n'Miracle' baby born in Gaza after airstrike kills heavily pregnant mother\n\nMs. Harris is scheduled to meet separately on Thursday with Mr. Netanyahu. She is also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' October 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\nMr. Netanyahu, last at the White House when former President Donald Trump was in office, is headed to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nRelationship of 40 years\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups-and-downs over the years. Mr. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Mr. Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Mr. Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Ms. Harris. It could also be a boon for Ms. Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Mr. Biden and Mr. Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nCrucial for Harris\n\nFor Ms. Harris, the meeting with Mr. Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinised by those on the political left who say Mr. Biden hasn't done enough to force Mr. Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her as insufficient in her support for Israel.\n\nA senior administration official, who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House, said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Ms. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Mr. Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Mr. Biden and Mr. Netanyahu.\n\nMr. Netanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nMr. Netanyahu, in a fiery address before a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, offered a robust defence of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes. He made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. {"uri": "8243812674", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:35:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:35:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:34:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_c97ce199-2430-5646-aa6c-2a943e9601de.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\nCardinals' TV ratings on record-low pace amid continuing distribution problems: Media Views Tammie Holland, longtime St. Louis radio personality, dies at 53 Third bear sighting reported in southern Illinois, sheriff says Ranch in Wildwood is sanctuary for abused miniature horses Woman from Valley Park drowns in Big River trying to help another canoeist Former St. Louis Rams lineman ordered to pay $500,000 to injured worker Kohn's Kosher Deli facing lawsuit of nearly $150,000 O'Fallon, Mo., woman charged with making politically motivated false child sex abuse claim Messenger: A disturbing twist in the case of security guards who tackled BJC patient Messenger: He fixed up his mobile home. He made it too nice. The city wants him out. St. Louis Public Schools halts hiring over questions on new administrator from Texas BenFred: So, you're looking to trade with the Cardinals. Who are you (realistically) targeting? BenFred: Smart contract stance lets Cardinals be nimble as Goldschmidt tries to salvage season Ankle injury interrupts Tommy Edman's rehab games, delays his return: Cardinals Extra Lawsuit accuses Archdiocese of St. Louis of allowing clergy to abuse children\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She was also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when Republican Donald Trump was president, will head to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups and downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her support for Israel as insufficient.\n\nA senior administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes.\n\nHe made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris said Thursday she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\n0 Comments", "source": {"uri": "stltoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-07-433764483", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:20:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:20:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:14:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/biden-pushes-netanyahu-in-tense-ceasefire-talks/article_e49b0783-199c-5cf5-81b0-6794fe304db6.html", "title": "Biden pushes Netanyahu in tense ceasefire talks", "body": "President Joe Biden pushed Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to quickly reach a Gaza ceasefire Thursday, with a friendly handshake masking tense ties and questions over the outgoing US leader's relevance.\n\nThe two leaders put on a good-humored show for the cameras as they met in the Oval Office at the White House, just four days after the 81-year-old Biden's stunning announcement that he would not seek reelection.\n\n\"From a proud Zionist Jew to a proud Zionist Irish American, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the State of Israel,\" Netanyahu said in tribute to Biden at the start of the Oval Office meeting.\n\n\"And I look forward to discussing with you today and working with you in the months ahead.\"\n\nBut Netanyahu, 74, was also set to meet separately with Vice President and presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris -- reflecting the new political reality of Biden being a lame duck for the next six months.\n\nHarris has been more outspoken on Gaza in the past and there has been speculation that she could adopt a tougher approach on Israel. Officials deny there is any \"daylight\" between her and Biden.\n\n- 'Compromise' -\n\nThe White House said Biden would keep pushing for a ceasefire and hostage release deal between Israel and Hamas, a potentially legacy-defining achievement if it happens.\n\nAnd it said it still believed that Netanyahu was ready for an agreement despite a fiery speech to the US Congress on Wednesday in which he vowed \"total victory\" against Hamas.\n\n\"The president will be reaffirming for prime minister Netanyahu that he believes we need to get there, and we need to get there soon,\" National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters.\n\n\"We can achieve a deal, but it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nBiden and Netanyahu later met the families of US hostages held in Gaza, many of whom have called on Netanyahu to reach a deal.\n\nProtesters chanted slogans outside a ring of metal barriers erected around the White House, following rowdy protests during Netanyahu's speech to lawmakers.\n\nHarris on Thursday condemned the \"despicable\" and \"unpatriotic\" burning of an American flag by protesters, after attempts by Donald Trump's Republicans to paint Democrats as pro-Hamas.\n\n- 'Final gaps' -\n\nWhile Biden has kept military aid flowing to Israel since Hamas's October 7 attacks, relations with Netanyahu have been deeply strained by Israel's conduct during the war.\n\nThe meeting is Netanyahu's first visit to the White House during Biden's presidency. They also met in New York last year and when Biden traveled to Israel days after the attacks and hugged Netanyahu at the airport.\n\nA senior US administration official said Wednesday that negotiations on a Gaza deal were in the \"closing stages\" and that Biden would try to close some \"final gaps\" with Netanyahu.\n\nIn a primetime speech on Wednesday explaining his decision to bow out of the election, Biden said he would \"keep working to end the war on Gaza.\"\n\nBut in a further sign of Biden's diminishing relevance, and Netanyahu's determination to play both sides, the Israeli will meet Trump in Florida on Friday.\n\nThe ex-president on Thursday urged Israel to quickly \"finish up\" its war in Gaza, warning its global image was being tarnished.\n\nThe Hamas attack on October 7 resulted in the deaths of 1,197 people in Israel, most of them civilians, according to an AFP tally based on official Israeli figures.\n\nOut of 251 people taken hostage that day, 111 are still being held inside the Gaza Strip, including 39 who the military says are dead.\n\nMore than 39,100 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's military campaign in the Gaza Strip since the war began, according to data provided by the health ministry of Hamas-run Gaza, which does not give details of civilian and militant deaths.\n\ndk/sst\n\nMore from this section\n\nOptimal Blue Launches {"uri": "8243820181", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:47:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:47:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:46:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/25/harris-describes-gaza-suffering-need-for-cease-fire-after-netanyahu-meeting/", "title": "Harris describes Gaza suffering, need for cease-fire after Netanyahu meeting", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Vice President Kamala Harris said Thursday that she had a \"frank and constructive\" meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House that included her concerns about the humanitarian situation in Gaza and the need to finalize a cease-fire deal.\n\n\"What has happened in Gaza over the past nine months is devastating,\" Harris told reporters after the meeting. \"We cannot look away in the face of these tragedies. We cannot allow ourselves to become numb to the suffering, and I will not be silent.\"\n\nHarris said she would \"always\" ensure Israel's ability to defend itself, and pointed to what she described as a \"hopeful movement\" in talks to secure a cease-fire. She said she told the prime minister during their meeting that \"it is time to get this deal done.\"\n\n\"Let's get the deal done so we can get a cease-fire to end the war. Let's bring the hostages home, and let's provide much-needed relief to the Palestinian people. And ultimately, I remain committed to a path forward that can lead to a two-state solution,\" Harris said.\n\nShe did not take any questions from reporters after giving her remarks.\n\nThe meeting took on higher stakes, amid the 2024 election shakeup, as Harris runs for president following Biden's decision to withdraw from the race. Harris missed Netanyahu's speech before a joint meeting of Congress on Wednesday because of a previously scheduled event in Indianapolis. Typically, the vice president presides over joint addresses.\n\nHours earlier, President Joe Biden hosted the Israeli leader in the Oval Office for a bilateral meeting and the two leaders met for roughly an hour with families of American hostages held hostage in Gaza.\n\nSpeaking to reporters in the Oval Office before the meeting, Netanyahu had thanked Biden for his 50 years of public service and his support of the state of Israel.\n\n\"Mr. President, we've known each other for 40 years, and you've known every Israeli prime minister for 50 years from Golda Meir. So from a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu said.\n\nBiden offered only a few words in response before the media left, recalling meeting with Meir and joking that he was \"only 12 when it happened.\"\n\nThursday marked the first time Biden and Netanyahu have met in person since Biden visited Israel shortly after Hamas' terrorist attack on Oct. 7.\n\nA senior administration official told reporters Wednesday that Biden planned to discuss his \"ironclad commitment to Israel's security, the very serious threats from Iran and from Iranian proxy and terrorist groups, including Hamas, Hezbollah, the Houthis.\"\n\nThe official said the two leaders were expected to speak \"in depth\" about developments in Gaza, including efforts to reach a cease-fire agreement and the humanitarian crisis. The administration believes that a deal \"is in the closing stages and it's reaching a point that we believe a deal is closable, and it's time to move to close that agreement,\" the official said.\n\nFor her part, Harris has been engaged on the Israel-Gaza conflict for the last 10 months, the official said, including participating in every call with Netanyahu, as well as critical meetings like those with hostage families.\n\nDuring a briefing Thursday, National Security Council communications adviser John Kirby told reporters that Biden was working with Netanyahu to fill gaps tied to striking a cease-fire deal.\n\nAsked whether Biden believed that Netanyahu wants to strike a cease-fire deal and that he is capable and willing to bridge the gaps, Kirby said: \"Yes, yes and yes. He has said so publicly himself. He wants to get the hostages home and the Israelis, the government, Prime Minister Netanyahu, has been working with us to try to get that deal over the finish line.\"\n\nIn his speech before Congress, Israel's prime minister thanked Biden \"for his tireless efforts on behalf of the hostages and for his efforts to the hostage families, as well.\"\n\n\"There will obviously be no daylight between the president and the vice president,\" the official said, adding they expect for a productive day because the Israelis will be at the White House for a while on Thursday.\n\nNetanyahu also thanked Biden for his leadership in his speech.\n\n\"I thank President Biden for his heartfelt support for Israel after the savage attack on Oct. 7,\" Netanyahu said. \"He rightly called Hamas 'sheer evil.' He dispatched two aircraft carriers to the Middle East to deter a wider war. And he came to Israel to stand with us during our darkest hour -- a visit that will never be forgotten.\"\n\n\"President Biden and I have known each other for over 40 years,\" he continued. \"I want to thank him for half a century of friendship to Israel and for being, as he says, a proud Zionist. Actually, he says, a proud Irish American Zionist.\"\n\nNetanyahu is scheduled to meet with former President Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago on Friday.", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", And how it does so matters,\" Harris told reporters after the meeting. She said she raised her serious concerns about the scale of human suffering in Gaza.\n\n\"I made clear my serious concern about the dire humanitarian situation there,\" she said. \"I will not be silent.\"\n\nHarris' remarks, which were sharp and serious in tone, reflected what could be a shift from President Joe Biden in how she deals with Netanyahu.\n\nHours earlier, Biden pressed for a cease-fire to the nine-month-old war in Gaza in his first face-to-face talks with Netanyahu since the president traveled to Israel days after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel and pledged American support.\n\nWhite House national security spokesperson John Kirby said gaps remain between Israel and the Hamas militants who run the Palestinian enclave in the drive for a ceasefire but \"we are closer now than we've been before.\"\n\n\"Both sides have to make compromises,\" Kirby said.\n\nState Department spokesperson Matt Miller said: \"I think the message from the American side in that meeting will be that we need to get this deal over the line.\"\n\nThe visit coincides with a shift in American politics. On Sunday, Biden, 81, stepped aside from the U.S. presidential race under pressure from fellow Democrats and endorsed Harris for the party's 2024 presidential nomination.\n\n\"We've got a lot to talk about,\" Biden said when he welcomed Netanyahu to the Oval Office.\n\n\"I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden.\n\nThe White House was ringed with extra security fencing to protect against protesters on Thursday.\n\nBiden and Netanyahu earlier met together with the families of American hostages held by Hamas. Representatives for the families told reporters after the meeting that they were hoping for a ceasefire deal that would bring the hostages home.\n\n\"We came today with a sense of urgency,\" said Jonathan Dekel-Chen. He said they were more optimistic of a deal since the first release of Israeli hostages from a previous ceasefire.\n\nSTRAINS IN BIDEN-NETANYAHU RELATIONS\n\nRelations between Biden and Netanyahu have been strained for months over Israel's Gaza offensive in which more than 39,000 people have been killed, according to health officials in Gaza.\n\nThe U.S. is a major arms supplier to Israel and has protected the country from critical United Nations votes.\n\nWhether Biden, who is now a \"lame duck\" president, a term used for officials who won't serve another term, or Harris, who is tied in many election polls with Republican rival Donald Trump, can have any influence on Netanyahu remains to be seen.\n\nOn Friday, Netanyahu travels to Florida to meet Trump.\n\nHarris has been aligned with Biden on Israel but has struck a tougher tone.\n\nThe conflict began on Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel from Gaza, killing 1,200 people. Israel launched a retaliatory assault.\n\nHamas-led fighters took 250 captives on Oct. 7, according to Israeli tallies. Some 120 hostages are still being held though Israel believes one in three are dead.\n\nDEFIANT SPEECH\n\nOn Wednesday, Netanyahu gave a defiant speech to the U.S. Congress in which he defended Israel's attacks on Gaza, saying anti-Israel protesters \"should be ashamed of themselves.\"\n\nThe Gaza conflict has splintered the Democratic Party, and sparked months of protests at Biden events. A drop in support among Arab-Americans could hurt Democratic chances in Michigan, one of a handful of states likely to decide the Nov. 5 election.\n\nBiden's desire for unity in the party in the drive to defeat Trump was cited on Wednesday night in an Oval Office address as a main reason why he decided not to seek reelection but to instead support Harris for the 2024 race.\n\nNegotiations on a long-sought cease-fire-for-hostages deal in the Gaza conflict appear to be in their closing stages, a senior U.S. official said on Wednesday.\n\nU.S. officials have made similar pledges before about a {"uri": "8243807523", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:28:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:28:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:27:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/netanyahu-meets-with-biden-and-harris-to-narrow-gaps-on-a-gaza-war-cease-fire/article_a53f01cc-f872-514b-bc01-8f170cd92f02.html", "title": "Netanyahu meets with Biden and Harris to narrow gaps on a Gaza war cease-fire deal", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met separately at the White House Thursday with President Joe Biden and likely Democratic nominee Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the war in Gaza and the possibility of securing a cease-fire deal.\n\nNetanyahu's first White House visit since 2020 comes a day after he gave a fiery speech to Congress and at a time of growing pressure in Israel and the U.S. to find an endgame to the nine-month war that's left more than 39,000 dead in Gaza and some 1,200 dead in Israel. Dozens of Israeli hostages are still languishing in Hamas captivity.\n\nBiden reiterated in their Oval Office meeting his calls for Israel and Hamas to quickly agree to a cease-fire deal that would bring home the remaining hostages, according to White House national security spokesman John Kirby. White House officials say the negotiations are in the closing stages, but there are issues that need to be resolved.\n\nPeople are also reading... Roses Discount Store in Marion set to close in August Roaming Buffalo Outpost moving from Rutherford Road to Marion's North Main Street Expanded grocery, new mural: Remodeled Marion Walmart shows off renovations McDowell alum, WCU pitcher aims for major league draft in 2025 2 teens who died after crash during Greensboro police chase had just finished middle school. A 15-year-old also died. Two Marion women charged with drug crimes Young child found wandering on road in Morganton alone; mother charged Catawba County mother charged in death of 9-month-old appears in court Marion's splash pad damaged in act of vandalism Avery County woman charged in McDowell for drug crimes Play by McDowell 14-year-old centers on Marion water treatment Three Lenoir residents charged; More than 400 grams of meth seized Art on Hickory oil tanker truck highlights efforts to prevent veteran suicide What is Soma Church? Hickory pastor talks vision, $4.65 million purchase of former CommScope building McDowell County man charged with three counts of extortion\n\n\"The gaps are closable,\" Kirby said. He added, \"But it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nHarris met with Netanyahu in her ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. She was also expected to press him on securing a deal to release the hostages kidnapped during Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel that launched the war.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as she welcomed the Israeli leader. \"We do indeed,\" he replied.\n\nThousands protested Netanyahu's visit in Washington, and Harris condemned those who were violent or used rhetoric that praised Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu, last at the White House when Republican Donald Trump was president, will head to Florida on Friday to meet with the Republican presidential nominee.\n\nThe conservative Likud Party leader Netanyahu and centrist Democrat Biden have had ups and downs over the years. Netanyahu, in what will likely be his last White House meeting with Biden, reflected on the roughly 40 years they've known each other and thanked the president for his service.\n\n\"From a proud Jewish Zionist to a proud Irish American Zionist, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the state of Israel,\" Netanyahu told Biden at the start of their meeting.\n\nA U.S.-backed proposal to release remaining hostages in Gaza over three phases is something that would be a legacy-affirming achievement for Biden, who abandoned his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. It could also be a boon for Harris in her bid to succeed him.\n\nFollowing their talks, Biden and Netanyahu met with the families of American hostages.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nFor Harris, the meeting with Netanyahu is an opportunity to demonstrate that she has the mettle to serve as commander in chief. She's being scrutinized by those on the political left who say Biden hasn't done enough to force Netanyahu to end the war and by Republicans looking to brand her support for Israel as insufficient.\n\nA senior administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity under ground rules set by the White House said there is \"no daylight between the president and vice president\" on Israel. Harris' last one-on-one engagement with Netanyahu was in March 2021, but she's taken part in more than 20 calls between Biden and Netanyahu.\n\nNetanyahu is trying to navigate his own delicate political moment. He faces pressure from the families of hostages demanding a cease-fire agreement to bring their loved ones home and from far-right members of his governing coalition who demand he resist any deal that could keep Israeli forces from eliminating Hamas.\n\nIn his speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday, Netanyahu offered a robust defense of Israel's conduct during the war and lashed out against accusations by the International Criminal Court of Israeli war crimes.\n\nHe made the case that Israel, in its fight against Iran-backed Hamas, was effectively keeping \"Americans boots off the ground while protecting our shared interests in the Middle East.\"\n\n\"Remember this: Our enemies are your enemies,\" Netanyahu said. \"Our fight, it's your fight. And our victory will be your victory. \"\n\nNetanyahu used his speech to praise Biden for his administration's support in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack. But he also noted action that Trump took during his four years in office that benefited Israel, including recognizing Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights, confronting Iran's aggression and moving the U.S Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nNetanyahu derided protesters who massed near the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, calling them Iran's \"useful idiots.\"\n\nHarris said Thursday she was outraged that some protesters tagged areas near the U.S. Capitol with pro-Hamas graffiti, expressed support for the militants, and burned a U.S. flag at Union Station.\n\nProtesters massed near the White House on Thursday chanted, \"Arrest Netanyahu,\" and brought in an effigy of the prime minister with blood on its hands and wearing an orange jumpsuit. A small number of counter-protesters wore Israeli flags around their shoulders.\n\nTrump and his Republican allies criticized Harris, who had events in Indiana and Texas on Wednesday, for skipping Netanyahu's address to Congress. White House officials said that her absence wasn't a slight and was solely due to scheduling conflicts.\n\nSen. JD Vance, the Republican vice presidential nominee, also skipped the speech to campaign. Biden, as vice president, skipped an address Netanyahu made to Congress in 2015.\n\nBiden speech: President appeals to Americans in solemn address Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to {"uri": "8243762507", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:28:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:28:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:28:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/biden-harris-push-netanyahu-on-gaza-ceasefire/", "title": "Biden, Harris push Netanyahu on Gaza ceasefire | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "US President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris pushed Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to agree a Gaza ceasefire Thursday, with friendly greetings masking tense ties as well as questions over Biden's relevance.\n\nJust days after the 81-year-old Biden's stunning announcement that he would not seek reelection, he and Netanyahu put on a good-humored show in their first meeting at the White House during Biden's presidency.\n\n\"From a proud Zionist Jew to a proud Zionist Irish American, I want to thank you for 50 years of public service and 50 years of support for the State of Israel,\" Netanyahu said in tribute to Biden at the start of the Oval Office meeting.\n\n\"And I look forward to discussing with you today and working with you in the months ahead.\"\n\nBut Netanyahu, 74, also met separately with Vice President and presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris -- reflecting the new political reality of Biden being a lame duck for the next six months.\n\nHarris has been more outspoken on Gaza in the past and there has been speculation that she could adopt a tougher approach on Israel. Officials deny there is any \"daylight\" between her and Biden.\n\n\"We have a lot to talk about,\" Harris said as they shook hands. Netanyahu replied: \"We do indeed.\"\n\n- 'Compromise' -\n\nThe White House said Biden would keep pushing for a ceasefire and hostage release deal between Israel and Hamas, a potentially legacy-defining achievement if it happens.\n\nBiden's administration said it still believed that Netanyahu was ready for an agreement despite a fiery speech to the US Congress on Wednesday in which he vowed \"total victory\" against Hamas.\n\n\"The president will be reaffirming for Prime Minister Netanyahu that he believes we need to get there, and we need to get there soon,\" National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters.\n\n\"We can achieve a deal, but it's going to require, as it always does, some leadership, some compromise.\"\n\nBiden and Netanyahu later met the families of US hostages held in Gaza, who called the meeting \"productive and honest.\"\n\n\"We feel probably more optimistic than we have since the first round of releases in late November,\" Jonathan Dekel-Chen, the father of American hostage Sagui Dekel-Chen, told reporters after the meeting.\n\nProtesters chanted slogans outside a ring of metal barriers erected around the White House, following rowdy protests during Netanyahu's speech to lawmakers.\n\nHarris on Thursday condemned the \"despicable\" and \"unpatriotic\" burning of an American flag by protesters, after attempts by Donald Trump's Republicans to paint Democrats as pro-Hamas.\n\n- 'Final gaps' -\n\nWhile Biden has kept military aid flowing to Israel since Hamas's October 7 attacks, relations with Netanyahu have been deeply strained by Israel's conduct during the war and suspicions that he may be stalling on a deal.\n\nA senior US administration official said Wednesday that negotiations on a Gaza agreement were in the \"closing stages\" and that Biden would try to close some \"final gaps\" with Netanyahu.\n\nIn a primetime speech on Wednesday explaining his decision to bow out of the election, Biden said he would \"keep working to end the war on Gaza.\"\n\nBut in a further sign of Biden's diminishing relevance, and Netanyahu's determination to play both sides, the Israeli PM will also meet Trump in Florida on Friday.\n\nThe ex-president on Thursday urged Israel to quickly \"finish up\" its war in Gaza, warning its global image was being tarnished.\n\nThe Hamas attack on October 7 resulted in the deaths of 1,197 people in Israel, most of them civilians, according to an AFP tally based on official Israeli figures.\n\nOut of 251 people taken hostage that day, 111 are still being held inside the Gaza Strip, including 39 who the military says are dead.\n\nMore than 39,100 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's military campaign in the Gaza Strip since the war began, according to data provided by the health ministry of Hamas-run Gaza, which does not give details of civilian and militant deaths.\n\ndk/aha\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox28spokane.com", "dataType": "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/66a1fb812d387image_.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9764144", "eventUri": "eng-9764144", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-10-07", "textStart": 2724, "textEnd": 2733, "freq": 2}], "sentiment":
